results.title: The Propaganda War Intensifies in Afghanistan as the Taliban Gain Ground
results.abstract: The effort to fend off panic and minimize losses has taken on outsize importance following the seizure of five provincial capitals by the Taliban.
results.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Fahim Abed

results.title: Olympics End as They Began: Strangely
results.abstract: The 32nd Summer Olympics came to a close in Tokyo. “We did it — together!” the president of the International Olympic Committee said, to lukewarm applause.

results.title: How an Obscure Swim Club Got a Say in Choosing Hong Kong’s Leader
results.abstract: Beijing is making it nearly impossible for the pro-democracy camp to win city elections. One tool: “grass roots” groups loyal to the government.
results.byline: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
org_facet: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong

multimedia.caption: A government billboard advertising the new electoral system in Hong Kong in May. Hundreds of so-called grass-roots associations were recently tapped by the government to play a key role in the city’s elections.

results.title: They Wait Hours to Withdraw Cash, but Most A.T.M.s Are Empty
results.abstract: Myanmar has been crippled by a cash shortage since the military seized power six months ago, plunging the Southeast Asian nation into a financial crisis.
des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

multimedia.caption: People lining up to withdraw cash in Yangon, Myanmar, in March. Since the military seized power in a coup six months ago, the Southeast Asian nation has been brought to its knees by a critical lack of cash.

results.title: With More Freedom, Young Women in Albania Shun Tradition of ‘Sworn Virgins’
results.abstract: A centuries-old tradition in which women declared themselves men so they could enjoy male privilege is dying out as young women have more options available to them to live their own lives.

multimedia.caption: Gjystina Grishaj, known by her male nickname, Duni, declared herself a man nearly 40 years ago in order to avoid a forced marriage at a young age.
Gjystina Grishaj, known by her male nickname, Duni, declared herself a man nearly 40 years ago in order to avoid a forced marriage at a young age.

results.title: Charged With Treason, a Genocide Survivor Opts to Fight, Not Flee
results.abstract: As a child, Theary Seng escaped Cambodia’s killing fields. After returning there as a human rights advocate, she angered the country’s strongman leader. But she refuses to be driven away again.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

multimedia.caption: Ms. Theary Seng in Phnom Penh, Cambodia’s capital, in January. There is “no democratic or civic space left” in the country, she said.

results.title: Jacob Desvarieux, Guitarist Who Forged Zouk Style, Dies at 65
results.abstract: His band, Kassav’, found millions of listeners as it held on to Caribbean roots while reaching out to the world. He died of Covid-19.

multimedia.caption: Jacob Desvarieux in 2009. A member of the band Kassav’, he created the Zouk style of music, which combined the Afro-Caribbean traditions of the French Antilles with sleek electronic dance music.

results.title: For Seniors Especially, Covid Can Be Stealthy

results.title: Behind the Haiti Assassination, Colombia’s Growing Mercenary Industry
results.abstract: Exporting soldiers has become a vast industry in Colombia, fueled by the country’s long U.S.-backed war, limited opportunity at home and growing demand abroad.
results.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Anatoly Kurmanaev

multimedia.caption: Members of the Colombian military on patrol last year. Each year, 10,000 servicemen retire, most with small pensions, little education and limited experience navigating the civilian world.

results.title: Is a Big Casino Footprint in a Tiny Principality a Good or a Bad Bet?
results.abstract: Liechtenstein, where gambling had largely been illegal until 2010, now has more casinos per capita than Macau or Monaco. Some critics worry that it’s more than the principality can handle.
